desc.size: Medium-sized tree to 15 - 22 m tall, trunk diameter 30 cm - 0.6 m. Trunk extends unbranched well into the crown. Crown narrow, oblong, with drooping branches.

part.partText: grayish brown, thick, with wide fissures between broad, flat-topped, interlacing, scaly ridges. Outer bark with alternating light and dark colored bands in cross section.
slender, brown, becoming grayish brown, smooth or finely hairy, with irregular corky, wing-like ridges. Leaf scars half-round, covered with a corky layer, having 4 - 6 bundle scars.
brown, 6 mm long, lance-shaped, pointed, scale margins hairy.

alternate, with short, hairy leafstalks; green, smooth, shiny above, paler and hairy beneath, 7 - 14 cm long, half as wide, oval to oblong; base rounded, nearly symmetrical; tip pointed, margins doubly-toothed, firm, many closely spaced veins. Leaves turning yellow in autumn.
with both male and female reproductive organs (perfect); in loose, drooping clusters; greenish red, small, calyx bell-shaped.
single-seeded, winged (samara), 1 - 2 cm long, oval, hairy, shallowly notched at the tip; seed cavity indistinct.

similarSpecies.comments: Ulmus thomasii is distinguished by having corky-winged twigs, leaves with a nearly symmetrical base, and hairy samaras. Ulmus americana has leaves with an asymmetrical base and samaras with hairy margins. Ulmus procera has smaller leaves with an asymmetrical base (5 - 8 cm long), and hairless samaras. Ulmus pumila also has smaller leaves (3 - 7 cm long), which are singly-toothed. Ulmus rubra has very rough leaves, forked veins near the leaf margin, rusty-colored bud hairs, and brown, hairy seed cavities. Characteristics of the hybrid U. x notha are intermediate of the two parents, U. pumila and U. rubra. The most distinctive features are the middle bud scales fringed with white hairs and the terminal scales fringed with reddish brown hairs. Celtis leaves, which are similar in appearance, have three main veins arising from the base of each blade.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Local in rich calcareous woods, often near streams; associated with hillside seeps. Has also been found in floodplains and fens.

notes.comments: The wood of Ulmus thomasii is used for boat frames, railroad ties, farm implements, piano frames, hockey sticks, veneer, and crates. This elm, as well as all native elm species, is susceptible to Dutch elm disease and phloem necrosis. See link to Dutch elm disease below.

etymology.comments: Ulmus is the Latin word for elm. Thomasii refers to the botanist David Thomas.
